report_title: Industry Report on Live Performance Theaters
executive_summary: Prominent musical productions dominate live performance theaters, which have prospered over the past five years. Still, the nature of live performance theaters allows for various live performances that appeal to every consumer preference. Boundless opportunities exist for artistic innovation and success as long as consumers can enjoy nonessential experiences. The outbreak of COVID-19 completely upended live performances when theaters nationwide had to shut down for over a year. Deserted theaters reversed growth for live performance theaters, with industry-wide revenue falling at a CAGR of 10.4% over the past five years and is expected to total $5.7 billion in 2024, when revenue will contract by an estimated 0.01%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Shows with High Production Costs Struggle to See Returns
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Shows with elaborate productions have been shown to be less and less profitable for producers. Consumer preferences have favored shows with simple sets and powerful stories instead of over-the-top, costly shows, leaving many expensive productions unable to recoup. As theaters grapple with dwindling audience attendance, exacerbated by soaring ticket prices, they find themselves caught in a cycle of financial strain, compelled to raise prices to offset declining revenues.

Social media has fast-tracked word-of-mouth recommendations, particularly among younger audiences, driving interest and ticket sales when demand is generally low. Stunt casting also captivates younger theatergoers. Many audience members wait by the stage door to meet the cast after the show, motivating fans to see shows starring their favorite celebrities.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Contemporary Adaptations Give Old Classics a Second Chance
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Despite significant customer interest, theatergoers show reluctance to pay premium prices for unfamiliar productions. Contemporary adaptations that reinterpret classic shows appeal to both fans of traditional theater and those who find older works outdated.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Institutional Art Forms Struggle to Against Competing Entertainment
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Traditional art forms like opera and ballet are finding it increasingly difficult to compete with modern entertainment options because of the cost of subscriptions and the accessibility of the material.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Finding New Ways to Spark Interest
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: For a long time, opera and orchestra companies have operated on a subscription structure, with a major portion of revenue coming from fans with long-standing memberships. Companies should focus less on selling people on subscriptions and more on single tickets. More flexibility makes it more welcome for those who are unfamiliar. Younger audiences have expressed a growing appreciation for performing arts, and companies can grab their attention by introducing new talent, composers and artists to generate excitement.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Financially Struggling Institutions Are in for a Tough Few Years
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Federal budget cuts and limited philanthropic donations will significantly impact financially struggling institutions, making it harder for them to sustain operations. Many donors today are more inclined to support climate, racial and social justice sectors over the arts, leading to limited funding for artists and theaters. With limited support and falling attendance, more theaters may be forced to cut staff to reduce costs, affecting the quality and quantity of productions. A few theaters, specifically those that are smaller or operate as non-profits, will be forced to shut their doors over the next few years as the financial difficulties become too great.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Elaborate Stage Productions Will Impact Costs
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Technological advancements enable large-scale productions to put on shows with more elaborate sound, lighting and set designs. Consumers are drawn to these embellished and expensive performances, allowing theaters to hike prices. As theaters attempt to attract larger audiences and justify higher ticket prices, marketing and purchase costs will rise. The rising use of technologically advanced equipment has and will continue to push up depreciation costs. These growing costs can hinder profit growth over the outlook period.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Live Streaming Will Present an Opportunity for Performing Companies
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Live performance theaters in the US will increasingly adopt recordings and live streaming to reach broader audiences and generate additional revenue. Sharing performances will enable theaters to expand to new markets, like customers who are interested in seeing live performances but have no access to live theater and cannot afford to travel.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Innovative Casting Choices Can Expand the Meaning of Plays and Musicals
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Innovative casting choices centered on diversity will transform the landscape of live theater. Future productions are increasingly celebrating diverse identities by integrating actors' backgrounds into the story, and using the opportunity to explore the work from a new angle.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry stage live performances of musicals, operas, plays, comedy, improvisational performances, mime and puppet shows. This industry includes dinner theaters, which also provide food and drinks.

threats: Time spent on leisure and sports

key_trends: Small-scale theaters can overcome competition by appealing to niche markets. Consumers in rural or suburban areas generate business for local theaters.
Large-scale productions avoid price competition by building a strong reputation. Positive reviews and a solid reputation make consumers willing to invest in tickets, emphasizing quality over pricing.

Classics are getting clever makeovers to stay relevant. Contemporary adaptations and immersive experiences are breathing new life into old favorites, drawing in both traditionalists and modern audiences eager for relatable themes.

Theaters can reach global audiences and generate extra income by streaming performances online. Though there are logistical challenges, partnerships with streaming services are a smart move for broader reach.

No live performance theater has more than a 5.0% market share since start-up costs are relatively low and economies of scale don't make a theater substantially more successful. As an art form, theater shows appeal to various consumer preferences.
Copyright laws grant theaters exclusive access to their work and revenue streams. Theaters can't reproduce performances without paying the copyright owner for licensing rights.
Theater audiences expand alongside domestic trips by US residents. Many consumers travel specifically to attend on- or off-Broadway shows, making it a popular vacation activity.

Wage costs for performance theaters have stayed mostly steady despite fluctuating attendance. Although some layoffs have occurred, the sector's need for human talent in various roles has kept wage costs relatively stable.

Theater depreciation costs have climbed thanks to high-tech upgrades. As productions become more technologically advanced, maintaining and replacing equipment has driven up expenses, although a lack of recent investments has temporarily reduced these costs.
New York attracts the most theater-goers of any other state thanks to the city's world-renowned theater district. Domestic and international tourists travel great distances to see Broadway shows.

The highly-populated Southeast provides a large pool of potential audience members. Small-scale theaters that open in Southeastern population hubs appeal to local consumers who prefer not to travel to attend a show.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment includes consumers under the age of 25. As many children and teens who attend live theater shows tend to land tickets from their parents or other older consumers, demand from this age cohort is underrepresented. While younger consumers enjoy live theater, they have limited income to spend on pricey shows.

This segment includes consumers between the ages of 25 and 54. Adults between the ages of 25 and 54 also purchase tickets for younger theater-goers, like children. According to Broadway League, the average Broadway audience member is 42.3 years old. Adults in this age group have higher disposable incomes than their younger counterparts and are more willing to make large discretionary purchases.

This segment includes adults over the age of 55. Older generations that grew up without technology are more familiar with live theater as entertainment, drawing them to live shows. Many consumers in this age group are retired and have more time to spend on leisure activities, like theater productions. A lack of consistent income also mitigates ticket purchases by older consumers.

products_and_services.product_description: A performance combining songs, acts, dance, and spoken dialogue.
Non-musical performances refer to a variety of theatrical genres like drama, comedy and improv.
Other live performances include symphonies and classical music shows, popular music performances, spoken word, dance performances, public appearances and speeches.
Individuals, businesses, unions, foundations and the government provide financial contributions and grants to support live performance theaters.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Most theater revenue comes from ticket sales, which fluctuate with disposable income and audience interest in live performances.

business_locations.location_description: Concentration in the Mid-Atlantic is driven by New York City, which has a significant number of theaters, capturing one-fifth of the nation's total.
California hosts the second-largest concentration of live performance theaters in the US.
The country's most populated region is home to many theater lovers.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Article I of the Constitution establishes copyright laws, guaranteeing artists exclusive rights to reproduce their work.
Piracy laws penalize any nonlicensed party who copies and distributes a work of art.
The US agreed to comply with the Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works in 1989.
The Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (the TRIPS Agreement) states that performers have the right to prevent fixation.

concentration_points.concentration_description: While a handful of notable companies operate the majority of Broadway theaters in New York, most other theater operators cater to niche audiences or local markets.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Low barriers to entry generate fragmentation
concentration_points.concentration_description: Federal funding for creative arts, including live performance theaters, fosters several new live performance theaters yearly.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Depreciation Grows as Performances Become More High-Tech
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Depreciation costs for live performance theaters are relatively high compared with other art and entertainment industries.
The growing popularity of streaming platforms and alternative entertainment options has diverted audiences from live performances to online content.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wage Costs Remain Steady Despite Attendance Fluctuations
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Theatrical productions require various employees, including parking lot attendants, accountants, actors, directors, producers, choreographers, musicians and set designers.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Theatrical productions require employees with various skill levels.
Consistent capital expenses for live performance theaters include renting performance venues and maintaining and updating lighting and sound equipment.

volatility_points.volatility_title: TRAVELERS IN THE US DRIVE THEATER ATTENDANCE
volatility_points.volatility_description: Attending a Broadway show is one of the most popular activities for New York tourists.

volatility_points.volatility_title: THEATER ATTENDANCE WAVERS ALONGSIDE CONSUMER SPENDING HABITS
volatility_points.volatility_description: Off- and on-Broadway shows are considered nonessential leisure activities for the average consumer.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: The Arts Present Boundless Opportunities for Innovation
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: As an art, live performance theaters can put on innovative shows that capture the attention of a target audience.
Large-scale theaters are innovating by using the latest technology to create realistic and fantastic sets.

FAQs.question: Is your revenue sensitive to changes in discretionary spending?
FAQs.answer: Live performance tickets are considered highly discretionary and therefore, in times of economic growth, demand for industry products tends to increase.

FAQs.question: Do demographic changes have an effect on company sales?
FAQs.answer: Individuals over the age of 25 account for over 90.0% of revenue and therefore the aging population across the US has benefited theaters.

FAQs.question: How well rounded are your products and services so as to mitigate sudden changes in demand?
FAQs.answer: Theaters host a variety of live performances including symphonies, musicals, plays, dances and speeches.

FAQs.question: If your company benefits from population density, are you located in high traffic areas to increase your exposure?
FAQs.answer: The majority of operators in this industry are concentrated in highly populated areas in order to provide efficiency.

FAQs.question: Have you established a strong internet presence through social media platforms in order to capture a larger audience?
FAQs.answer: Companies have increasingly taken advantage of social media to market their talents at a lower cost.

FAQs.question: What has your company done to update facilities in order to enhance the consumer experience?
FAQs.answer: Theaters typically install the latest sound systems and lights in order to attract high-quality performers.

FAQs.question: Do you offer membership agreements, tickets or passes that may be subject to state or federal regulation?
FAQs.answer: Some larger theater companies offer bundled ticket options.

FAQs.question: Do you work with any industry associations?
FAQs.answer: Theaters work with and are represented by several industry associations.

FAQs.question: Is your company's profit margin in step with major competitors?
FAQs.answer: Average profit is lower than a number of its competitors.

FAQs.question: Does your company have to purchase new equipment on an annual basis?
FAQs.answer: While some equipment only needs to be replaced when new technology comes out, other equipment must be replaced often.

FAQs.question: How do you promote word-of-mouth recommendations? How do you maintain your reputation?
FAQs.answer: Establishing a good reputation will stimulate many repeat and new consumers.

FAQs.question: What methods do you have in place to encourage donations and grants? How do you take advantage of government subsidies?
FAQs.answer: Many organizations benefit from public monies.

FAQs.question: What programs do you provide to educate the community? What other ways do you educate the community?
FAQs.answer: A priority activity is to develop appropriate curriculum-based programs for schools.

FAQs.question: How has federal funding for creative arts affected your company thus far? How could you adapt if federal funding decreased?
FAQs.answer: The higher the level of public funds directed toward performances, the higher the caliber of creative artists.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in per capita disposable income? How will your services be affected by fluctuations in income levels?
FAQs.answer: Theater tickets are a discretionary purchase and demand for this sector is sensitive to changes in the macroeconomic climate.

FAQs.question: How are you competing with the expanding array of other leisure options? How is your company affected when time spent on leisure decreases?
FAQs.answer: The more leisure time people have, the more likely they will attend live performance theater.
